prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Setting A - 95
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
a) PN 2-1 PO+ 2-1
b) PO J=5/2-3/2, Ω=1/2
c) PS J=11/2-9/2, Ω=1/2 PS J=11/2-9/2, Ω=3/2 Not all components are covered. v=0 and v=1 are covered simultaneously.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Spectral setup We place three basebands to cover transitions from PO, PN, and PS. An extra baseband is placed to cover a continuum region. In all science goals, where relevant the width of the baseband is chosen to also cover the hyperfine structure of the transition. For all science goals spectral averaging is used to achieve a frequency resolution of 1.5 – 2 km/s. The observations will probe the dust-formation region and outwards, and we expect the lines to probe velocities >3km/s, resulting in line-widths of >6km/s. We will hence spectrally resolve the line profiles and be able to determine the expansion velocity of the emitting region.
Sensitivity requirements: The main target of this science goal are the transitions from PO and PN. Based on IRAM 30m observations we estimate the peak flux in the PO and PN lines to be 28 mJy/beam and 100 mJy/beam, respectively. 0.9 hours of observations will give an rms of 2.8 mJy/beam, allowing us to detect PO and PN at a S/N of 10 and 36, respectively. See Table 1 for flux estimates.
Spatial scales: In order to constrain the dust formation zone, we need to probe the wind on scales of a few stellar radii. The begin of the dust formation zone lies at approx. 8-10 stellar radii, and is expected to extend to approx. 150 stellar radii. At the distance of IK Tau, a resolution of 0.45 arcsec corresponds to approx. 35 stellar radii. The observations hence allow us to probe the dust-formation zone and outwards. We do not expect the emitting region to be larger than 3” in diameter, hence we do not require ACA or total power observations.

Spectral setup: We place four basebands covering transitions from PO, PN, and CP. In all science goals, where relevant the width of the baseband is chosen to also cover the hyperfine structure of the transition. For all science goals spectral averaging is used to achieve a frequency resolution of 1.5 – 2 km/s. The observations will probe the dust-formation region and outwards, and we expect the lines to probe velocities >3km/s, resulting in line-widths of >6km/s. We will hence spectrally resolve the line profiles and be able to determine the expansion velocity of the emitting region.
Sensitivity requirements: The main target in this science goal are the PO and PN transitions. Based on IRAM 30m observations we estimate the peak flux in the PO and PN lines to be 45 mJy/beam and 250 mJy/beam, respectively. 0.5 hours of observations will give an rms of 4.5 mJy/beam, allowing us to detect PO and PN at a S/N of 10 and 56, respectively. See Table 1 for flux estimates.
Spatial scales: In order to constrain the dust formation zone, we need to probe the wind on scales of a few stellar radii. The begin of the dust formation zone lies at approx. 8-10 stellar radii, and is expected to extend to approx. 150 stellar radii. At the distance of IK Tau, a resolution of 0.3 arcsec corresponds to approx. 20 stellar radii. The observations hence allow us to probe the dust-formation zone and outwards.We do not expect the emitting region to be larger than 3” in diameter, hence we do not require ACA or total power observations.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Setting C - 235
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
a) PN 5-4 PNO 19-18
b) HCP 6-5
c) PNO 18-17
d) PS J=25/2-23/2, Ω=1/2 PS J=25/2-23/2, Ω=3/2
PO falls outside of sideband when PN is prioritised.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Spectral setup We place three basebands to cover transitions from PN, PNO, and HCP. In all science goals, where relevant the width of the baseband is chosen to also cover the hyperfine structure of the transition. For all science goals spectral averaging is used to achieve a frequency resolution of 1.5 – 2 km/s. The observations will probe the dust-formation region and outwards, and we expect the lines to probe velocities >3km/s, resulting in line-widths of >6km/s. We will hence spectrally resolve the line profiles and be able to determine the expansion velocity of the emitting region.
Sensitivity requirements: The main target of this science goal is the transition from PN. Based on SMA observations we estimate the peak flux in the PN line to be 200 mJy/beam. 0.5 hours of observations will give an rms of 20 mJy/beam, allowing us to detect the PN line at a S/N of 10. See Table 1 for flux estimates.
Spatial scales: In order to constrain the dust formation zone, we need to probe the wind on scales of a few stellar radii. The begin of the dust formation zone lies at approx. 8-10 stellar radii, and is expected to extend to approx. 150 stellar radii. At the distance of IK Tau, a resolution of 0.18 arcsec corresponds to approx. 13 stellar radii. The observations hence allow us to probe the dust-formation zone and outwards. We do not expect the emitting region to be larger than 3” in diameter, hence we do not require ACA or total power observations.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Setting D - 266
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
a) PH3 ground state line PH2 lines in the sideband
b) P(15)N 6-5 H(13)CP 7-6

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Spectral setup: Two basebands are separated in two parts in order to cover the PH3 and PH2, and the H13CP and P15N lines, respectively. Two additional continuum basebands are placed in the other sideband. In all science goals, where relevant, the width of the baseband is chosen to cover the complete hyperfine structure of the transition. For all science goals spectral averaging is used to achieve a frequency resolution of 1.5 – 2 km/s. The observations will probe the dust-formation region and outwards, and we expect the lines to probe velocities >3km/s, resulting in line-widths of >6km/s. We will hence spectrally resolve the line profiles and be able to determine the expansion velocity of the emitting region.
Sensitivity requirements: The main target in this science goal is the PH3 transition. Based on results of PH3 observations towards the carbon AGB star IRC+10216 and NH3 observations towards IK Tau we estimate the peak flux in the PH3 line to be approx. 100 mJy/beam. 0.5 hours of observations will give an rms of 0.01 Jy/beam, allowing us to detect the PH3 line at a S/N of 10. See Table 1 for flux estimates.
Spatial scales: In order to constrain the dust formation zone, we need to probe the wind on scales of a few stellar radii. The begin of the dust formation zone lies at approx. 8-10 stellar radii, and is expected to extend to approx. 150 stellar radii. At the distance of IK Tau, a resolution of 0.15 arcsec corresponds to approx. 10 stellar radii. The observations hence allow us to probe the dust-formation zone and outwards. We do not expect the emitting region to be larger than 3” in diameter, hence we do not require ACA or total power observations.

Spectral setup: We place four basebands to cover transitions from PN, PO, and PNO. In all science goals, where relevant the width of the baseband is chosen to also cover the hyperfine structure of the transition. For all science goals spectral averaging is used to achieve a frequency resolution of 1.5 – 2 km/s. The observations will probe the dust-formation region and outwards, and we expect the lines to probe velocities >3km/s, resulting in line-widths of >6km/s. We will hence spectrally resolve the line profiles and be able to determine the expansion velocity of the emitting region.
Sensitivity requirements: The main targets in this science goal are the PO and PN transitions.Based on SMA observations we estimate the peak flux in the PO and PN lines to be 50 mJy/beam and 200 mJy/beam, respectively. 0.5 hours of observations will give an rms of 5 mJy/beam, allowing us to detect PO and PN at a S/N of 10 and 40, respectively. See Table 1 for flux estimates.
Spatial scales: In order to constrain the dust formation zone, we need to probe the wind on scales of a few stellar radii. The begin of the dust formation zone lies at approx. 8-10 stellar radii, and is expected to extend to approx. 150 stellar radii. At the distance of IK Tau, a resolution of 0.15 arcsec corresponds to 10 stellar radii. The observations hence allow us to probe the dust-formation zone and outwards. We do not expect the emitting region to be larger than 3” in diameter, hence we do not require ACA or total power observations.

Spectral setup: We place two basebands to cover transitions from PO and PN. Two extra basebands are placed to cover continuum regions. In all science goals, where relevant the width of the baseband is chosen to also cover the hyperfine structure of the transition. For all science goals spectral averaging is used to achieve a frequency resolution of 1.5 – 2 km/s. The observations will probe the dust-formation region and outwards, and we expect the lines to probe velocities >3km/s, resulting in line-widths of >6km/s. We will hence spectrally resolve the line profiles and be able to determine the expansion velocity of the emitting region.
Sensitivity requirements: Based on SMA observations we estimate the peak flux in the PO and PN lines to be 100 mJy/beam and 150 mJy/beam, respectively. 1 hour of observations will give an rms of 10 mJy/beam, allowing us to detect PO and PN at a S/N of 10 and 15, respectively. See Table 1 for flux estimates.
Spatial scales: In order to constrain the dust formation zone, we need to probe the wind on scales of a few stellar radii. The begin of the dust formation zone lies at approx. 8-10 stellar radii, and is expected to extend to approx. 150 stellar radii. At the distance of IK Tau, a resolution of 0.13 arcsec corresponds to approx. 9 stellar radii. The observations hence allow us to probe the dust-formation zone and outwards. We do not expect the emitting region to be larger than 3” in diameter, hence we do not require ACA or total power observations.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The role of phosphorus in circumstellar gas and dust chemistry remains unclear. Phosphorus monoxide (PO) and phosphorus nitride (PN) have been observed in the circumstellar environment of the oxygen-rich AGB star IK Tau and the red supergiant VY CMa, and PN, CP, CCP, HCP, and PH3 have been observed towards some carbon-rich evolved stars. The derived high abundances for PO and PN in the oxygen-rich winds cannot be accounted for by current chemical models. Furthermore, from the models, PS and PH3 are expected to be among the major P-carriers but these molecules have not been detected yet in oxygen-rich evolved stars. We propose to observe PO, PN, PH3, and PS in the circumstellar environment of IK Tau and aim at constraining their spatial distribution throughout the circumstellar envelope. A sensitive search for these molecules using ALMA will help us further quantify the amount of phosphorus in the wind. The proposed ALMA observations will help constrain the total P-budget of the CSE, the depletion of P onto dust, and the formation on dust-grain surfaces of P-bearing species.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Astronomy, Leuven, Catholic University
Department of Physics and Astronomy, Uppsala University
Onsala Space Observatory, Chalmers University of Technology
